author: m.kalinin
content:
Before we have crystallized `safe` and `unsafe` by adding them to the JSON-RPC spec and thus implementations (though we already have `safe` in Engine API but this is not the end yet), I would like to get back to the naming question once again. Are we happy in general with these terms?

My main concern is that `safe` is too abstract, for instance, `finalized` is safe too. Also, why would ethereum node serve an `unsafe` block to a user -- my concern from the other side. A bit of a background:
- "finalized" block -- irreversible Casper FFG checkpoint, it has a set of assumptions
- "safe" block -- irreversible block as per LMD-GHOST, it has another set of assumptions

"finalized" is strongly associated with Casper FFG (as casper is a finality gadget), the main goal of this algorithm is to add finality property to the chain. It would be great to have something similar in the context of LMD-GHOST to just borrow it but we don't.

What comes to my mind as an alternative to `safe`:
- `reliable` -- the block is reliable in some context
- `solid` -- as alternative to the above
- `durable` -- the last word from ACID abbreviation

Any other suggestion are very welcome.

author: m.kalinin
content: `safe` isn't necessarily `justified`. Safe will be justified in the first version as we have decided on the recent ACD, but once we have a safe block rule fully designed then `safe` will be much closer to the head than `justified`

author: m.kalinin
content: Relations between all these blocks are as follows: `finalized <= justified <= safe <= latest`
